channel.title: Comments on: DATEFROMPARTS and DATETIMEFROMPARTS functions in SQL Server Denali CTP3
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.content:encoded:
Erik,

Yes, I don’t think VFP was the first here, sure.

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.content:encoded:
That’s not true, actually. I believe Rushmore technology was originated in FoxPro. There are many unique features in FoxPro that none of other languages have. And ability to work with data locally in a very convenient way is a unique for FoxPro and none of the products can beat it.

Anyway, it’s a general perception of the audience not familiar with the product and I don’t want to dwell into this topic.

item.title: By: Iris
item.dc:creator: Iris
item.description: Great observation, Naomi! But I think Erik is right. Visual FoxPro is not really the type to actually come up with something original lol.
item.content:encoded: Great observation, Naomi! But I think Erik is right. Visual FoxPro is not really the type to actually come up with something original lol.

item.title: By: Erik
item.dc:creator: Erik
item.description: I highly doubt Visual FoxPro was the first one to think of SomeFunction(year, month, day) that returns a date, Naomi.
item.content:encoded: I highly doubt Visual FoxPro was the first one to think of SomeFunction(year, month, day) that returns a date, Naomi.

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.content:encoded:
Nice.

BTW, Visual Foxpro also has date and datetime functions that allow to specify year, month, date.

So, two more stuff borrowed from VFP ðŸ™‚
